Congress finds that women are paid 80 cents for every dollar men earn, with the earnings gap persisting for the past two decades. The gap is widest among working parents, as some women prioritize family responsibilities over career advancement or higher earnings. According to a 2001 Government Accountability Office study, female full-time managers earned less than male counterparts in 1995 and 2000. The earnings gap between female and male full-time managers widened in 7 out of 10 industries between 1995 and 2000. Women make up 46% of the workforce but only 12% of corporate officers. Discrimination in acceptable roles for men and women and workplace perceptions may contribute to the earnings gap. The Department of Labor projects a 1% annual growth rate in the US workforce. The Department of Labor projects a 1% annual growth rate in the US workforce, partly due to the increasing presence of women. The Department of Labor projects a 1% annual growth rate in the US workforce, partly due to the increasing presence of women. A Center for the Study of Women and Workplace Policy is established. The Secretary of Labor will grant funds to establish the "Center for the Study of Women and Workplace Policy" at an eligible university. The Center will compile and analyze data on gender wage disparities and disseminate its findings annually to the public through a website. The "Center for the Study of Women and Workplace Policy" will maintain a website for data and findings of recent studies. It will publish best practices guides for businesses and families, focusing on workplace equity, retaining women, and promoting a family-friendly workplace. The Center for the Study of Women and Workplace Policy will publish a best practices guide for families, including information on employer policies, strategies for addressing workplace inequity, and recent findings. Subsequent editions of the guides will be updated and revised. In this Act, an eligible university is defined as a public university with specific research areas and facilities. The university must conduct research on gender differences in faculty careers, work experiences of non-tenure-track faculty, and policies related to work and family for tenure-track faculty. The Act requires eligible universities to research gender differences in faculty careers, work experiences of non-tenure-track faculty, and work and family policies for tenure-track faculty. It also mandates the creation of a national clearinghouse for gender-related information. Recipients of grants must report on fund usage and evaluate the success of the funded Center. Grant amounts are specified for fiscal years 2006 through 2010. For fiscal years 2006 through 2010, the Secretary will provide a $1,000,000 grant to an eligible university to implement the Act.
